how to achieve self-mastery from the philosophy of Friedrich Nietzsche.
Friedrich Nietzsche is a German philosopher who lived in the second half of the 19th century.
He is widely famous for his critique on morality and religion and also on conventional philosophical
ideas.
He wrote several books, like “Thus Spoke Zarathustra”, “Beyond Good and Evil”,
“The Birth of Tragedy”, and “The Twilight of the Idols”.
He also considered himself a psychologist, paving the way to the psychoanalysis of the
20th century and he is often considered to be among the great modern thinkers, together
with Sigmund Freud & Karl Marx.
But he is also considered a precursor of existentialism, highlighting the importance of freedom and
finding meaning in an otherwise meaningless world.
Nietzsche believed that the fundamental drive of all living things is the so-called Will
to Power, which is often seen as the impulse to overcome one’s environment, the impulse
to grow, expand, and explore, but the greatest power one can possess, in Nietzsche’s view,
is not the power over other people or environment, but the power over your own self.
Mastering yourself is the foundation of all the other skills and powers you have and it
is the one you have to focus on first in order to achieve greatness.
To help you understand the ways in which you can achieve self-mastery, here are 7 lessons
we can learn from the philosophy of Friedrich Nietzsche:
Obey yourself first
Nietzsche says: “He that cannot obey himself, shall be commanded.”
By contrast with Schopenhauer, who in his pessimistic view believed in a Will that directs
our entire life and that we are incapable of escaping it, Nietzsche also talked about
a Will, but he called it “the Will to Power”, which is a power meant to overcome resistance.
This resistance can be from other people or from the environment.
When we do not have enough will power, it means we are not in control, we lack self-discipline,
we can’t follow our own plans that we so carefully laid, because of some temporary
urges, impulses or emotions.
When we can’t follow through with our own plans and strategies to win in life, then
the other people, more in control of their own behaviour and with a cooler mind, can
take advantage of us and end up commanding us.
Nietzsche considered two types of morality: slave morality and master morality.
If you follow a slave morality, you will be commanded by your community, by peer pressure,
you will be made to doubt yourself and you will end up living a shadow life, just going
with the flow, not having a real goal in life for yourself, you will live your life to make
other people happy.
But, if you have clear goals in life and you can obey yourself by following through with
your plans and act in the direction of your own dreams, you will follow a master morality,
meaning that you will be able to act independently from others, in the direction of your own
dreams.
For example, consider that your goal in life is to be a millionaire, but you do not have
enough money to invest in your business and you have to keep your regular job for a while.
Your managers at work and your colleagues constantly demand more and more from you,
and you cannot simply ignore their demands, you will forget in time about your initial
goal, you will over-commit to your regular job, accept new promotions and responsibilities,
you will go with the flow, building a career that you do not even want.
Your work environment, the circumstances, the people, will push you towards a destination
you do not want, you are thus commanded.
By contrast, if you obey yourself, you would never stay overtime at work, you would constantly
try to reach in your spare time more and more potential investors for your business, you
would educate yourself everyday about the business you want to make, you would never
lose sight of your entrepreneurial goal.
Obeying yourself is mandatory for achieving anything great in life.
Strengthen your will
To quote Nietzsche: “I want to make asceticism natural once again.”
Nietzsche was firmly against the three “ascetic ideals” - poverty, humility, and chastity,
and his attack on them was part of his attack on Christianity.
However, in his earlier work, he saw some good practical use of so-called natural asceticism.
He acknowledged that there is an advantage in one’s capability to mastering one’s
own will.
The less you obey your biological and emotional urges, the more free you are.
By the practice of asceticism in the form of abstinence and periods of fasting of all
kinds, for example, you gain more control over your own life, you will learn how to
control your biological and emotional urges, giving you a great advantage compared to other
people who are just slaves of their instincts.
You cannot achieve self-mastery if you cannot resist the temptations to grab that cookie
on the plate or if you can’t take alone time for a few weeks to prepare for an important
exam or if you can’t stop smoking.
For example, if you are struggling to quit smoking, some self-help tips would be to try
to think positively, think that you have the power to really succeed in quitting smoking,
make a real plan, decide on a date from which you will stop, consider changing your diet,
and think of what activities you should do to replace smoking for example, chewing gum,
or going for a run and so on.
If you are easily irritated by the demands of others, experiencing a high degree of stress
each day and feeling incapable of going through all the hardship at work, a method to strengthen
your will can be through meditation to decrease the stress level of everyday life.
Meditation will give you the strength and calmness to push through the hardship without
stressing yourself too much.
If you are struggling with maintaining concentration at work due to wasting too much time on social
media, you could for a few weeks, temporarily delete all the social media applications from
your phone, avoid social gatherings and so on.
Instead, you can spend this time focusing on practicing a skill or learning something
new.
These techniques are ways to achieve self discipline, helping us to become stronger
and more in control of our will.
Master your temper Nietzsche teaches us: “The growth of wisdom
may be gauged accurately by the decline of ill temper.”
If the growth of wisdom can be measured by the decline of ill temper, this implies that
by knowing how to control yourself, your moods, you are proven to be a wise person.
Nietzsche was all for the idea of self-control, but he did not believe that we have a complete
freedom of choice or free will.
Indeed, we cannot control our likes and dislikes, we cannot change our personality so quickly,
we can’t decide what to want and what not to want, but we can control our attitude,
our behaviour in our journey to reach our goals.
By mastering your temper, keeping at bay all the destructive urges like breaking things,
shouting at others or being violent, you would create a space for your mind to analyze the
event from different perspectives before doing anything or before opening your mouth.
The more we stop ourselves and think before acting, the more time we have to really evaluate
a situation and make better decisions and thus, we become “wise”.
For example, if you are a short-tempered person, always reacting sharply to any injustice or
what you perceive as injustice, you might benefit from this teaching.
If you are working on a project at your job and you are in charge of a team, you might
get particularly frustrated or angry at someone who does not do their job properly.
If you shout at that person in front of other people for doing a lousy job, you will make
them lose their self-confidence, resulting in them making even more errors and you would
permanently damage your working relationship with them.
They may have skills and talents you don’t know anything about which you might be able
to use in another project.
But since you damaged the relationship, you would never know about them.
If you are wiser, you would have a private conversation with that person, explain your
frustration, give some suggestions how they can improve or ask them to think about how
to improve, make a plan together on how to deal with the situation and follow through.
In this way, everybody would be happier, working in a more stress-free environment and not
only will you not damage your working relationships, you may actually improve them, and so in turn,
even improve the performance of your team in the long run.
Master your decision-making process In the words of Nietzsche: “Acquire power
over your yes and no and learn to hold and withhold them in accordance with your higher
aims.”
Nietzsche wrote that “God is dead”, which became one of the most famous sentences written
by him.
The death of God is metaphorical, Nietzsche did not believe in the existence of God and
this death represents the fact that Christian values have weakened.
In his book “Thus Spoke Zarathustra”, Nietzsche described a modern society where
the religious values have weaken, but, instead of being replaced by positive and inspiring
values, they were replaced by nihilism, a belief that all values are baseless and that
nothing can be known or communicated.
Thus, for Nietzsche, this death of God is not entirely positive, because the decay of
Christian morality has put in danger the entire moral belief system of the Western world.
In a world without God, Nietzsche proposed the concept of overman as a solution to combat
the danger of a world decaying into nihilism.
The Overman is a superior and ideal version of the human being, capable of living a fulfilling
life.
Such a human being would be a master of himself, capable of conducting his life in the absence
of an imposed set of morals.
He would be able to set goals and dreams to follow and, when finding himself in a situation
where he must choose between different options, he is strong enough to resist the pressure
of other people and of the environment and he is capable of saying no to anything which
does not serve his higher aims.
Nietzsche considered that the greatness of us is that we are a bridge between animals
and overman, not an end-goal.
To be more like the overman, we need to master the way we make decisions in life as the decisions
we make often set the course of our entire lives.
We will perhaps never be strong enough to say no all the time as we live in an interdependent
world, but we should try to care more about our goals and learn to say no at least when
the demands are outrageous.
To master the skill of decision-making, it is important to first know what your goals
are in life.
Let’s say, for example, you discover that your main life goals are to have enough free
time to spend with your family while still having the financial resources to live comfortably
and go on the occasional foreign holiday, but you do not care too much about making
vast fortunes.
Your friend proposes that you join in a business venture which while potentially highly profitable,
would leave you no time for leisure for several years at least.
In this case, as attractive as potential fortunes are, it is not inline with your life goals.
You need to have the strength to say no, no matter how tempting his proposal is.
Always think of your end goal before committing to anything.
Master your body
As we learn from Nietzsche: “There is more intelligence in your body than in your best
wisdom.”
Many philosophies and religions consider that human beings are split in two: a physical
part and a spiritual part.
Nietzsche was very much against such a split, considering that we do not pay enough attention
to our body, that there is no such thing as “another world”, it is only this physical
world that really exists.
Oftentimes, philosophers fantasize of other metaphysical worlds, of a world of ideas,
separated from this physical reality.
Nietzsche proposed an end of these ideal worlds, separated from the physical one and he proposed
the returning to the innocence of physicality.
The best figure for such a return is Dionysos, the god of wine, embodying the idea that our
animal instincts are the root of any form of spirituality.
Nietzsche considered himself as the last disciple of Dionysos.
Today, science has demonstrated how important it is to have a healthy body and a healthy
lifestyle in order to have a healthy mind.
We need to feed ourselves well, to have a normal sexual life, to exercise regularly,
to spend more time in the sun and fresh air.
Our animal nature needs care and consideration.
The more we listen to our body, to its needs and desires, the more balanced we can be in
life, and our mind would function much better when given the best physical conditions.
We need to schedule enough time for taking care of our body, for example, we can decide
to exercise 30 minutes every day, to take a short walk in your neighbourhood once every
couple of days, to eat fresh fruits and vegetables, spend more time connecting with our partner,
go for a hiking at least once a month and so on.
Your body is your temple, it is your delicate machine which must be properly taken care
of every day.
It is the base of your entire life and, according to Nietzsche, even the base of your intelligence
and spiritual life.
Master your heart Nietzsche advises us that...
“One ought to hold on to one's heart; for if one lets it go, one soon loses control
of the head too.”
Nietzsche was one of the smartest men of his time, he was a well-known professor at Basel
and the youngest one ever to take such a position, he was a prodigy, a great intellectual.
However, his romantic life was not so happy.
Nietzsche had never married or had a known relationship with any woman, and at the age
of 44, he went mad after allegedly seeing a horse being whipped in the Italian city
of Turin, saying to it “I understand you”.
His collapse in Turin might have been a consequence of his contracting syphilis.
The only things we know for sure about his love life is that he was infatuated with Lou
Salome, the young and brilliant Russian woman who later became a known figure of feminism
and of psychoanalysis and also with Cosima Wagner, the wife of Richard Wagner.
In spite of his failures, he constantly thought about love and marriage, but ultimately he
gave more consideration to his work, to his legacy in the field of philosophy.
We might never know if he could have had another destiny if he would have gotten married and
had a more balanced lifestyle, with not so much solitude, perhaps syphilis would not
have struck him in such a severe way.
One has to hold on to his heart not to lose his head and Nietzsche’s life might serve
as a counter-example.
We can have great ambitious plans for our career, but it is important to give enough
attention to our sentimental life too.
Human affection is transformative and can heal us.
If we encounter setbacks in our professional or financial lives, we can replenish our soul
with the love of our spouse, of our family and close friends.
Otherwise, if we choose a life of absolute solitude, we would not have enough love to
protect us when we need it the most.
Therefore, it is important to make time to find the right people to join you in your
journey, people who respect you and give you love and encourage you to have confidence
in yourself.
Make a list of all the attributes a partner should have to fulfill your needs for love
and affection and make sure the people who enter your life have these attributes.
Mastering your heart means managing your love life and close friendships.
It is as important - perhaps even more important - than mastering your finances or mastering
the skills needed for your profession.
If one loses one’s heart, one might lose one’s “head”, too.
Emotional health sustains the mental health of a person.
Find happiness in self-mastery In our final quote from Nietzsche for this
video, he says: “The most spiritual human beings, as the strongest, find their happiness
where others would find their destruction”.
Nietzsche’s philosophy is considered to have a psychological but also somehow mystical
side, encouraging some severe practices of self-constraint, followed by creating a new
self.
Nietzsche imagined this new self as an entirely new being, an overman, someone who can overcome
his human nature, achieving true freedom.
In Nietzsche’s view, there are three stages of becoming an overman: camel, lion and child.
The camel phase is a symbol of self-control or self-mastery.
Before becoming an overman, you need to find the strength to search for the truth, to learn
and develop yourself.
In other words, you need to experience things, to say Yes to learning and self-control.
The camel does not endure hardship only to reach an end goal, but also it can find happiness
in the journey towards it.
These 3 metamorphoses can also be applied on a smaller scale.
For example, consider you grew up in a poor family, in a poor country and you wish to
become financially wealthy one day.
People around you have 9-to-5 jobs, working in factories, watching a lot of television
and meeting in bars.
In order to reach your goals, you need to doubt this kind of lifestyle and you need
to find other role models, for example, you can read the biographies of the most successful
people, and you can find role models on the internet, people who came up from poor backgrounds
to achieve high level success, and you can start working on yourself, copying their strategies.
You might give up your free time, give up watching T.V. or meeting with friends, you
might enroll in online courses to learn business skills and join networks of successful people.
Others would probably think that you are too hard on yourself when you wake up at 5 am
to workout or when you turn down the offer to hang out with friends and instead stay
in to follow an online course, but there is satisfaction in the hardship that drives you
towards your goals.
And, one day, when you complete your learning, you can become the lion who will break their
chains, who says No to their previous lifestyle, and who will find their freedom in a completely
new one, in achieving their goal, becoming a new person in the end - the child.
Becoming a better person requires you to be able to endure the hardship.
But, as long as you have a clear vision over the end goal, you will enjoy the process and
you will be able to find happiness in self-mastery.
